title: Overview
body:
For many managers, working for the humanitarian sector is a positive experience. Coordinating challenging programmes can give you a great sense of achievement. The frontline teams you manage are critical in improving the lives of people in need, and this can be very fulfilling, for both you and your teams.

Along with these very rewarding aspects, you and your teams may also find physically and emotionally demanding aspects in your job. In addition, you may find that you have stress related to large workloads and challenging workplace relationships with colleagues and managers. For example, responding to the human costs of disasters, such as wars, floods, earthquakes, famines, or refugee crises can have a negative impact on the way you and your teams of humanitarian workers feel. Similarly, humanitarian workers in your organisation may have to deal with longer-term issues such as poverty, hunger and disease, as well as high workloads and insecure environments.

As a manager, it’s important to be aware of the issues faced by your team as well as dealing with organisational challenges, such as high workloads and limited resources and planning.

As well as organisation and field stressors, you and your teams will also have individual, personal-life stressors, such as family and relationship issues.

It’s understandable that these situations may make humanitarian workers feel unhappy, tense or angry. However there are things that you can do to help your teams prepare, navigate, and recover from these job hazards.

This course will get you thinking about the stress that you and your teams experience as part of your roles.

We’ll help you identify the warning signs to look out for in humanitarian workers and in your colleagues.

You’ll also find strategies and techniques to help humanitarian workers cope with various stressful situations and encourage them to play their part in managing their wellness and resilience.

We’ll also provide you with guidance on embedding a culture of wellness and resilience within your organisation.

Some of the material you read during the course may trigger thoughts and personal experiences. Additional support and resources will be available throughout the course.

Let’s begin by looking at the goals we hope to help you achieve by the end of this course.

title: About this Course
body:
This course aims to equip you with information about various wellness and resilience techniques that you can use in stressful situations.

By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Identify the nature of stress
Describe the importance of staying well and resilient
Identify signs of stress
Develop strategies to effectively manage and reduce stress
Develop and strengthen personal resilience and wellbeing
Put in place practices and organisational structures that foster wellness and resilience.

title: Stress in Humanitarian Aid Workers
instruction: Select each of the headings to find out about major stressors.

_items.title: Security Risks
_items.body: Being associated with an NGO is a security risk in itself. You also have the additional risk of being in insecure environments where the humanitarian work happens, for example, wars, natural disaster, etc. In such situations, there may be restrictions on movement due to security concerns. There is also the risk of accidents, especially if your job involves travel.

_items.title: Witnessing Suffering and Devastation
_items.body: Due to the nature of your job, you will see others suffer and hear stories of terror, personal tragedy, suffering, and devastation.

_items.title: Job Insecurity
_items.body: The threat of job insecurity is often a challenge, because of short term contracts and the fact that the programme may finish or the organisation may leave the area.

_items.title: Organisational Issues
_items.body:
Like job insecurity, organisational issues can impact your stress and wellbeing. These issues include unclear job descriptions, lack of information about the crisis, poor preparation and briefing for the task and lack of boundaries between work and rest.

If you begin to feel your wellbeing is not valued and your efforts are not being acknowledged and appreciated, this can also have an impact within your teams, creating a bad atmosphere at the workplace.

_items.title: Difficult Working Conditions
_items.body: As a humanitarian worker, you may experience difficult working conditions. You may live and work in physically demanding and unpleasant conditions. These conditions often come with heavy workloads, long hours and lack of privacy and personal space, as well as being potentially isolated and not able to move freely.

_items.title: Relationship Issues
_items.body: You may experience problems in communication or have difficulties with relationships at work.

_items.title: Separation from Loved Ones
_items.body: Working away from home can be very challenging as you’re separated from your families and friends.

title: Importance of Managing Stress
body:
To deliver effective humanitarian responses you must be competent, well trained, healthy (both physically and mentally) and ideally, supported throughout your whole working lifecycle.

Although it’s clear that more support is currently needed for wellness and resilience within the humanitarian sector, we’re looking to you to help make that change through a collaborative effort.

We all have a part to play in working towards this common goal. As an individual, you’re responsible for managing your own wellbeing and by looking out for the wellbeing of your colleagues. Why not begin by telling your colleagues about this course?

It’s also important to know when it’s time to flag issues, if you feel unsupported or at risk.

title: Mind-Body Impact of Stress
body: This section focuses on helping us to understand the impact of stress on our brain and explains why we react to stress and trauma in different ways.
instruction: Select each of the hotspots to see how stress affects various parts of the brain.

_items.body:
Amygdala

The amygdala is a small region of the brain that responds to environmental threats by acting like an alarm bell. It releases stress hormones, which prepare your body to flee from or fight off danger. The amygdala is much ‘quicker’ than the pre-frontal cortex, which is where our logic, sense of self, and decision-making capabilities lie.

Long-term effects

Your amygdala can become sensitised if you encounter ongoing, terrifying or life-threatening events. This means that it can take less and less to activate the amygdala and send you into high-alert. It is normal to feel super-alert or ‘jumpy’ in the days that follow a scary or life-threatening event, but these feelings should decrease gradually over time.

However, if your amygdala has become sensitised, your ‘alarm bell’ will continue to release stress hormones even when you’re not truly in danger.

Hippocampus

The hippocampus is a complex part of the brain that does many things. This area of the brain is very important to memory and helps provide context to the environmental cues that the amygdala is reacting to. This part of the brain can turn off the amygdala if there is no need for alarm, or if the situation can be dealt with, without the need to activate the fight or flight response.

Long-term effects

Neuroscientists have found evidence that hippocampal volume (or the number of cells in the hippocampus) is lower in the brains of people who have experienced repeated trauma, this can cause cells in the hippocampus to shrink among other things. This can compromise the brain’s ability to lay down and consolidate new memories.

It might also make you feel more easily triggered by stressful events and less in control. Fortunately, cell regeneration can occur in the hippocampus, meaning that both amygdala sensitisation and hippocampus damage are potentially reversible.

Fight-Flight-Freeze

The autonomic nervous system is responsible for triggering a fight-flight-freeze response. It works by monitoring our environment for any association with danger from our past.

Danger triggers can be sights, sounds or smells, for example.

When the amygdala senses danger, it automatically releases stress hormones, such as adrenalin and cortisol. These hormones affect multiple functions in the body such as:

  • Increase in the rate and strength of the heartbeat, resulting in raised blood pressure.
  • The blood is then driven from the skin and viscera to the skeletal muscles, coronary arteries, liver, and brain.

    • As this happens, our bodies prepare to run away, fight if necessary or freeze depending on the situation. It's our natural instinct to protect ourselves from danger.

title: Flow of Energy: From Bored to Burned Out
displayTitle: Flow of Energy: From Bored to Burned Out
body:
Let’s start by understanding the flow of our energy from bored state to burned out state.

When we have large quantities of positive energy, we are in the green zone. This is the zone where we are at our best. The green zone has productive pressure and energy.

When pressure and demands continue to build, we end up shifting out of the performance zone into the amber zone. This is where stress starts showing its effects on our mind and body.

If we stay for long in the amber zone, we end up landing in the red zone. We start feeling the symptoms of burnout and we can feel hopeless and exhausted. Not only is this bad from a health and a performance perspective, but it also affects our ability to connect well with others.

title: Green Zone: Good Stress
body:
Did you ever think pressure can be good for us?

In fact, productive pressure keeps us challenged, engaged and enthusiastic and drives us to achieve! We need this pressure to get us going.

Positive stress comes from inside – our own drive, desires and motivation. It also comes from outside – in the requirements of the work, the challenge to persevere in tough times and to stretch ourselves to achieve our objectives.

Positive stress is usually short-term. It motivates us to move into action and get things done. When we’re in the positive stress zone, we perceive an adverse situation as an opportunity or challenge that needs to be overcome and will lead to a good outcome.

This type of stress can even be enjoyed!

title: Green Zone: Resilience
body:
When we’re in the green zone, our resilience to stress is at its best. As humanitarian workers, we need to be resilient. What does being resilient mean?

It refers to our ability to regain our positive coping strategies that may have been compromised during times of high stress. Resilience determines how quickly we get back to our steady state after a stressful situation has passed. It helps us to bounce back in the face of adversity.

It is easier to observe the effects of resilience than to define what makes a person resilient. Like intelligence or personality, resilience is a complex construct and it may look different for people in various contexts. It may even change for you at different points in your life. Some of the core components of resilience include having reasons for hope and optimism, meaning and purpose, a willingness to engage challenges, and a strong network of social support.

title: Red Zone: Burnout
body:
Do you know that humanitarian workers are at high risk of experiencing burnout?

This is because in their working situations, stress accumulates and stays at high levels for extended periods of time leading to a burnout.

Burnout is not an event, it’s rather a process in which we start showing cumulative stress reactions after getting exposed to emotionally demanding situations for longer time periods.

Occupational situations that typically contribute to burnout are:

  • Conflict between individual values and organisational goals and demands.
  • Lack of managerial and/or social support.
  • Overload of responsibility.
  • Role confusion.
  • Sense of having no control over quality or outcome of work.
  • Little emotional or financial reward.
  • Existence of inequity, lack of respect.
  • Consistent exposure to traumatic material.

Credit: Video created by Save the Children.
instruction: Select Play to watch the video about burnout in humanitarian workers.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Humanitarians work to change the lives of vulnerable people. It’s incredibly rewarding and inspiring. But, it can also be tough and challenging. In our line of work, there’s a high risk of burnout. That feeling that you're about to physically or mentally collapse due to a combination of overwork, stress and the emotional demands of your role. Everybody, even the most experienced among us, has a breaking point. Where that breaking point is and what contributes to it is different for each of us.

So, what are the causes of burnout?

Work-related stress is a key factor. In short doses, stress can be useful. It can motivate us to get work done. However, when the stress is too high or lasts too long or demands become too many or unreasonable, it can start to drain us. Feeling like you have little or no control of your work or not seeing an impact from it are also big factors. Also, being held to overly high standards with little recognition can negatively affect you.

Lifestyle factors contribute to burnout. Humanitarians often put work above all else even our own health. Being away from friends and family is part of the job and can be challenging. Sometimes you might feel like you have no one to speak with and other times like they are demanding too much from you.

What signs of burnout should you look out for?

Burnout is a gradual process that occurs over an extended period of time. The earlier you catch it, the better. Watch out for signs that you may be struggling. For example,

  • A loss of self-confidence and not knowing what to do.
  • Feeling emotionally worn out with regular mood changes: irritability, tearfulness and emotional exhaustion.
  • Feeling detached, cut off and wondering “What’s the point anymore?”
  • Difficulty focusing and an inability to get a good night’s sleep.
  • Hiding from your problems by isolating yourself or self-medicating with alcohol or drugs.
  • A decline in your general health and taking longer to recover when you're sick.

These are warning signs to seek support.

How can we look after ourselves?

Share your workload; delegating tasks is healthy and gives others the chance to excel.

Speak to those around you; having someone to listen to you and rely on is incredibly important for your wellbeing. Ask them to watch out for worrying changes in your behaviour. Also, check in with your line manager, if you need more support or a break, let them know.

Although, it’s not always easy, make an effort to be healthy; scheduled meal times, a balanced diet, a good night’s sleep, exercise and relaxation are all vital. There’s no shame or guilt in taking time for your own wellbeing. The healthier you are, the more good you can do for others.

_items.title: Physical
_items.body:
Signs of physical stress may include:

  • Sleep disturbance
  • Change in appetite
  • Rapid heart rate/breathing
  • Easily startled
  • Exhaustion
  • Headaches
  • High blood pressure
  • Insomnia
  • Back pain and other chronic tension-linked pain
  • Stomach complaints

_items.title: Emotional
_items.body:
Signs of emotional stress may include:

  • Mood swings
  • Over-emotional
  • Irritability
  • Emotional numbness
  • Anger
  • Depression/sadness
  • Anxiety/worry

_items.title: Mental
_items.body:
Signs of mental stress may include:

  • Difficulty concentrating
  • Confusion
  • Disorganised thinking
  • Forgetfulness
  • Difficulty making decisions
  • Disturbing dreams or nightmares
  • Intrusive thoughts
  • Lack of focus

_items.title: Spiritual
_items.body:
Signs of spiritual stress may include:

  • Shattered world view
  • Questioning values
  • Loss of faith in God or higher power (or the opposite, sudden religious/spiritual devotion)
  • Feelings of emptiness
  • Loss of meaning
  • Discouragement
  • Loss of hope, sense of purpose
  • Doubt
  • Loss of sense of connection

_items.title: Behavioural
_items.body:
When we experience high levels of stress, we sometimes cope or compensate with behaviours that increase our vulnerability to stress. Often these can be behaviours that distract us from the immediate stress symptom, but cause other problems later on.

Signs of behavioural stress may include:

  • Risk-taking: neglecting safety and physical needs
  • Over or under eating
  • No energy
  • Aggression
  • Withdrawal/isolation
  • Compulsive behaviour
  • Overwork
  • Increased conflict in relationships
  • Increased use of alcohol, smoking
  • Abuse of prescription drugs or other drugs
  • Addictive behaviours
  • Unsafe sex
  • Procrastinating

title: Social Support: Techniques
body: Your social support network is made of friends, family, peers and colleagues.

_graphic.alt: A humanitarian worker giving a doll toy to a child

instruction: Select each of the categories to find out tips and suggestions to build your support network and strengthen your safety net in each of these groups.

_items.title: Friends
_items.body:
• Be proactive and make intentional efforts to build social connections.
  • Build a network of friends by taking part in local activities that are available to you.
  • Stay connected to friends at home through social media, over email or Skype calls and conversations.

_items.title: Family
_items.body:
• Before you leave for any field work, make a plan with your family on how you can stay in touch.
  • When you are away, send short messages throughout your day, rather than waiting for the time to write a long email or have a lengthy Skype call.
  • Talk to your partner or family about their day, don’t just talk about your work.
  • Try to keep the conversation light when you return, give yourself a week or two to allow time for your brain to function normally.
  • Show interest in even the mundane daily parts of life that you may have missed.
  • Let your partner know that they come before work and are your highest priority.
  • Take time off to invest in the relationship.

_items.title: Colleagues
_items.body:
• Engage in peer to peer relationships with your work colleagues.
  • Take breaks together as a way to develop positive relationships with the people you engage with in your work.
  • Create a peer support network in your office.
  • Create opportunities for social activity in your office.
  • Make time to have lunch/breaks with colleagues.
  • Online communities and other initiatives can also help share the burden and build relationships on common experiences.

title: Health and Wellbeing: Eat Well
body: Eating well can improve your mood and provide the nutrients and energy you need to promote stamina and help keep you healthy.
instruction: Select each icon and follow our tips to help you eat well and stay healthy.

_graphic.title: A table full of food items, Multiple water bottles on a table, Four glasses of wine and alcohol of varying sizes on a table.

_items.body:
Healthy and Mindful Eating

Mindful eating can improve digestion and helps regulate your appetite.

  • When it’s possible, make healthy choices when you do your food shopping.
  • In many humanitarian contexts, a cook is provided or if food is prepared, the food may be extremely limited. 
  • Try to switch off your mind and enjoy the food you are eating as much as possible. If you are worrying about work, your body will be in stress mode and your digestive system won’t function effectively.
  • Just as your car would not run well on poor quality fuel or no fuel at all, our bodies and brains function much better when we provide them with the right type of fuel.

_graphic.alt: A table full of food items.

_items.body:
Drink Enough Water

Did you know that if you feel thirsty, your body is already dehydrated?

By the time you feel thirsty you’ve already lost 2 to 3 percent of your body fluid. This lowers your blood volume, making your heart work harder to pump blood to your brain. Staying hydrated is one of the easiest ways to help ourselves function well.

  • Keeping hydrated is key for maintaining health and stamina. Headaches, fatigue and lack of concentration are all symptoms of dehydration.
  • Water keeps every part of your body functioning properly and with no sugar or calories, water is the best choice for keeping you hydrated.
  • Drink water regularly throughout the day - a helpful rule is to take a minimum of 6 gulps at a time, and to drink even if you don’t feel thirsty.

_graphic.alt: Multiple water bottles on a table.

_items.body:
Limit your Consumption of Alcohol

Some people may turn to alcohol as a coping mechanism, to help you switch off and forget the stresses of the day, but excess alcohol can actually make you feel more stressed due to the fact that alcohol is a depressant.

Drinking too much alcohol disrupts your sleep and may give you a hangover the next morning, which isn’t a great way to start your day. Long-term overuse of alcohol can lead to serious conditions, such as diabetes and heart disease.

_graphic.alt: Four glasses of wine and alcohol of varying sizes on a table.

Repetitive activities

Find an activity you enjoy such as walking, running (if possible), yoga, mindfulness, exercise videos, skipping rope or yoga. Anything that keeps you active! There are lots of apps available to help you in many of these different areas. Look in the Resources section to see some suggestions.

title: Being Active: Effects on Stress
body:
Even if there isn’t a gym available, there are lots of ways you can be active. You can also do exercises in the office or team house. Any exercise counts as long as you raise your heart-rate.

Being active has a positive effect on your body and helps reduce stress.

When you exercise new brain-cells grow in a critical area of the brain necessary to process stress. This is the same area of the brain that is damaged by toxic stress and is also responsible for memory and mood regulation.

Try and engage in exercise when you can throughout your day. By including your colleagues, you will also have a positive influence on them and their wellbeing.

By making exercise part of your daily routine, it’s easier to stick to as over time you will get into a routine and it will feel like less of an effort. Different things motivate or discourage different people. Think about what truly motivates you to exercise and think about the daily, progressive steps you can commit to that will get you there.

A helpful tip is to exercise in a group, this makes it more fun and you can push each other to be successful in sticking to your routine.

title: Personal Management
body:
In addition to managing our health and wellbeing and having strong social supports, it’s also important to pay attention to our:

  • Preparedness
  • Meaning and motivation
  • Adaptability and resourcefulness

    • Let’s find out more about each one through the eyes of Mira, who has just arrived in her field location after accepting a role as a Protection Officer.
instruction: Select each of the orange buttons to find out more.

frontImage.alt: On her way to the field location, Mira browses her phone as she walks down the street with a trolley suitcase.

_items.backBody:
Preparedness

Mira realised when she arrived that she knew very little about the culture and political context of where she was working. During the first few weeks of her employment, she feels under prepared and she’s not sure she has the skills to do her job. Mira approaches her line manager and they decide that she will do some online job-related skills training to make sure she has the correct skills. A member of the team will also spend some time with her briefing her about the culture and the context. Mira begins to feel much more confident about her role and her understanding of where she’s working.

Meaning and Motivation

Mira finds great meaning in her work and she feels that she is making a difference in the lives of the children she interacts with. After a few very difficult and stressful weeks, she starts feeling like she doesn’t want to go to work anymore and she starts wondering why she chose this role. She decides to approach a trusted colleague and they talk about the meaning of what they are doing. They decide to set up a regular staff meeting to talk about positive events that have happened in the week, not just about the problems they are experiencing. She also decides to keep a journal to document things she feels grateful for and the positive interactions she has each day.

frontImage.alt: Mira is in the coffee shop, waiting for her colleague to join her.

_items.backBody:
Adaptability and Resourcefulness

Mira is having a conflict with a colleague and feels that they can no longer work together. Whenever they are in the same room, they argue and she’s feeling hopeless about the situation. Mira decides to talk to her line manager about it and he suggests that she invites her colleague for coffee and has more of a social conversation. Mira decides to do this and to her surprise her colleague accepts. She finds out during coffee that her colleague has been under a great deal of stress at home and that he’s taking his anger out on colleagues in the office. Mira realises that she needs to look at the situation differently and she talks to her colleague about what he needs for support and how they can work better together. Their relationship improves and Mira reflects on the importance of looking at situations from different angles to see if there are other solutions to problems.

title: Risk Factors
body:
Research has identified several factors that influence your likelihood of experiencing challenges following chronic or traumatic stress.

These factors fall into two categories; situational and personal.

Situational
  • This looks at how much a person is likely to be affected by a certain crisis, this is often determined by the nature and type of event.
Personal
  • This looks at temperament, personal traits and mental wellbeing factors and how historical events such as childhood adversity or mental health problems may affect how someone reacts to trauma.

_graphic.alt: Humanitarian worker writing.

title: Risk Factors
instruction: Select each of the titles to find out more about risk factors.

_items.title: Nature and Intensity
_items.body: Research suggests that humanitarian workers who witness personal and intentional acts of human cruelty are more likely to experience enduring trauma reactions, compared with those who witness an impersonal or accidental traumatic event, such as the destruction caused by a hurricane.

_items.title: The Length of Exposure
_items.body: The length of exposure to stressful and traumatic situations is also a risk factor, the longer you’re exposed, the risk of enduring trauma reactions increases.

_items.title: Multiple Stressors
_items.body: Another risk factor is around the number of stressors you experience at the same time. Multiple, significant life-events, such as the death of a parent or relocating internationally that coincide with the crisis event, are likely to make you more vulnerable to experiencing trauma reactions.

_items.title: Past Intense Traumatic Experiences
_items.body:
You may have experienced personal traumatic experiences in your past, according to research at least one third of humanitarian workers have undergone personal traumatic events prior to any experiences they may encounter in the field. For some of you, this has been the motivating factor to engage in humanitarian work, through to a desire to help others in need.

The nature and intensity of traumatic events you’ve experienced in the past is also a risk factor.

_items.title: Previous Psychiatric Illness
_items.body: Those with a prior history of psychiatric illness, especially those who have experienced acute stress disorder or post-traumatic stress disorder, tend to be more vulnerable to experiencing trauma again.

_items.title: Lack of Social Support
_items.body: People we know well, who are kind and trustworthy, play an important role in protecting us from the effects of stress and trauma. Recent research suggests that those with low levels of social support are 4 times more likely to experience traumatisation and 2.5 times more likely to experience some form of physical illness.

_items.title: Temperament and Personality
_items.body: If you have a generally negative or pessimistic outlook or you are anxiety-prone, you’re more vulnerable to reacting more frequently and intensely to stressful events, and may be more prone to being traumatised.

title: What is a Critical Incident?
body:
A critical incident is an event which has significance to you and can overwhelm your normal ability to cope.

It can include traumatic incidents such as carjacking, robbery or kidnapping, but can also be the death of a close colleague or the illness of a child.

It’s characterised as something that is sudden, unexpected and overwhelms your normal coping strategies.

_items.body: “The incident occurred on our return from the field to Nyala. After spending the night in a small village, we communicated with the base and got the green light to drive to Nyala. Seven kilometres from the village, we found ourselves in the middle of an ambush. There were five or six armed people. They stopped us. The whole time in the field, we had a bad feeling something was going to happen, but we didn’t know what it would be. We could not escape our fate. They ordered us out of the car, made us lay face down on the ground and beat us with sticks. They stole everything, but they were convinced there was more. We didn’t have more. We had already spent all our money in the field.”

_graphic.alt: A man opening the door of a car and pointing his gun at someone who is sitting inside.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 2
_items.body: “The whole incident lasted about an hour and a half. In the end, they let us drive away, but without anything. It was very frightening. When we got home, I wasn’t able to go to the field for four months. I had nightmares, I was afraid to get in a car, and I felt so angry.”

_graphic.alt: Antonio, with a traumatic expression on his face.

title: Know the Signs
body: As a manager, dealing with a critical incident that affects your staff can be one of the most challenging parts of your job. In additional to managing your own needs, it helps to know what others could be experiencing.
instruction: Select each picture to learn about the common signs of acute stress.

_graphic.title: A hand holding a stick with a lot of force, A dark night with a tornado appearing, A shadow of a person standing near the window.

_items.body:
Physical

  • Difficulty sleeping.
  • Feeling hyper alert or unable to relax.
  • A strong 'startle' response.
  • Changes in appetite.
  • Headaches or upset stomach.

_graphic.alt: A hand holding a stick with a lot of force.

_items.body:
Emotional

  • Intense feelings of anger, anxiety, shame or guilt.
  • Lack of enjoyment of things you used to enjoy.
  • Feeling numb or out of touch with yourself.
  • Unreasonable blame of self or others for the event or how it was handled.
  • Fear or other distressing feelings when reminded of the event.

_graphic.alt: A dark night with a tornado appearing.

_items.body:
Mental
  • Difficulty concentrating.
  • Repeated or unwanted thoughts of the event.
  • Inability to remember important pieces of the event.

_graphic.alt: A shadow of a person standing near the window.

title: Act
body: Now, let’s look at the things we can do in the immediate aftermath of a critical incident to help manage stress.
instruction: Select each of the hotspots to find out more common feelings and reactions.

_graphic.alt: alt text

_items.body:
Exercise

Exercise helps our bodies process stress-related chemicals, reduces muscle tension, releases ‘feel-good’ chemicals called endorphins, helps us stay generally fitter and healthier, and improves our sleep. This is one of the single most effective stress management strategies.

Rest

You may feel exhausted after the event and it’s important to get lots of rest to assist in recovery.

Take a break

When we experience something traumatic, we can feel out of control and struggle to make sense of the chaos. It takes time to accept what has happened and to learn to live with it. It’s important to give yourself time and take breaks when you need to.

Talk to others about it, when you are ready

Most people who experience a traumatic event need support and understanding from those around them to help them recover. It can be a relief to talk about what happened. Take things at a pace that you feel comfortable with.

Reflect, meditate and write down your thoughts and feelings in a journal.

Activities such as mindfulness and writing help you to reflect on what has happened and begin the healing process.

Ensure that you feel safe and secure

Safety is essential after a difficult event. Make sure that you are in a safe location and getting back into a routine will help you to feel more secure.

Seek help such as counselling

If you feel overwhelmed by what has happened, you feel that life isn’t returning to normal, and are having symptoms that are worrying you, reach out for professional support. Your manager can help you to identify where you may seek support.

title: What is Vicarious Trauma?
body:
Vicarious trauma is the stress of caring about others who have been exposed to trauma and comes with cumulative exposure over time. It is the emotional toll of doing humanitarian work.

Let’s look at the story of Mohammad to understand how it can affect people.
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.title: Vicarious Trauma: Part 1
_items.body: “For the past 12 years, I’ve been living in conflict zones and battling with one inside of myself. Trauma lives in our bodies, it hides away and comes to visit us when we least expect it. It comes up in our dreams, our memories, our thoughts and our actions. It colours our choices and prevents us from being clear about what we need. Over the first few years, I gathered traumatic experiences like badges to be proud of. I lived through bombs, robberies, fighting and witnessed suffering that is unimaginable. It’s hard to know what was ‘the worst’, but there is one experience that has stayed with me.”

_graphic.alt: A man standing in a critical incident area.

_items.title: Vicarious Trauma: Part 2
_items.body: “I was working in a hospital in the Central African Republic and a young girl in the feeding centre wasn’t getting better. She would sit and stare at the wall, as would her mother. Not interacting with each other. Not moving. I was working with local counsellors and we began to ask more questions. It turned out that the girl and her mother had witnessed all of the children in her village being forced into a grass hut and burned alive by the Junjaweed (a militia group that operates in Western Sudan and Eastern Chad). We went to visit the village, saw the burned skeleton of the hut and the graves and with that came a profound feeling of hopelessness in humanity. How could a human being do this to children? For years after, I’ve thought about them. After seeing so much suffering, I feel exhausted. What is the point of doing this work, and how is what I’m doing of any help?”

_graphic.alt: A baby receiving medical care, in his mother’s arms.

title: Know the Signs
body:
The signs of vicarious trauma can be quite diverse, a person may show several signs of stress.

Common indications of vicarious trauma include: intrusive thoughts, feeling numb, unable to tolerate strong emotions, increased sensitivity, cynicism, despair, guilt in relationship to engaging in enjoyable activities, difficulty setting boundaries with beneficiaries, tendency to overcommit at work, decreased interest in enjoyable activities, irritability and spiritual depletion or crisis of faith.

displayTitle: Coming Home: The Reverse Culture Shock
body:
The periods of rest and relaxation, when returning from the field, also provide you with an important opportunity to work on your wellness and resilience. It can be difficult, however to adjust to home life after spending periods of time in a contrasting and stressful environment.

Let’s look at two accounts from humanitarian workers and their experiences of returning home.

Select each of the stories to find out more.

JamillaarrowSamarrow

_items.title: Working Away
_items.body: Although I’m part of the national staff team, I live and work away from my family. So, I only get to see them during my holidays and breaks.

_graphic.alt: Jamilla hugs her father, as she returns home from the field.

_items.title: Refugee Camp
_items.body: I work in a refugee camp, which is a one hour flight away from the city where my family lives.

_graphic.alt: A refugee camp.

_items.title: 6 Months Away
_items.body: This is the longest time that I’ve been away. I haven’t been able to take a break in over 6 months.

_graphic.alt: Calendar showing a date marked.

_items.title: Disorientated
_items.body: When I got home for my break, my parents organised a party with all my friends and family but I felt really disoriented.

_graphic.alt: Jamilla’s family having a barbeque to celebrate the return of their daughter.

_items.title: Can’t Connect
_items.body: I slept all the time and haven’t felt like I can socialise with my friends and family.

_graphic.alt: Jamilla sleeping on her bed at home.

_items.title: Trying to Adjust
_items.body: I’m staring at the hundreds of bottles of shampoo, overwhelmed by the choice. Why do we have so many choices?

_graphic.alt: A shelf in a supermarket showing variety of shampoo bottles.

_items.title: Anger and Frustration
_items.body: Anger, frustration bubble up and I run from the shop crying, not having bought anything.

_graphic.alt: Sam looking frustrated, standing in the corner of an alleyway.

_items.title: No sense of Purpose
_items.body: When I was in the field, I had structure and a purpose. Now that I’ve come home, the days stretch in front of me.

_graphic.alt: Humanitarian workers passing boxes to each other.

_items.title: No one Understands
_items.body: No one understands, or wants to listen to what I’ve been through and I feel so alone.

_graphic.alt: An isolated person carrying a sack on his shoulders on a dry, sandy road.

_items.title: Next Mission…?
_items.body: Even though I’m exhausted, I’m thinking about signing up for another mission right away.

_graphic.alt: Life boats with a set of life jackets lying on the ground.

title: Common Feelings and Reactions
body:
It’s very common to feel overwhelmed when returning home from an assignment. You may be extremely tired if you’ve been in an intense work situation and it can feel disorienting coming home. It can also be challenging to describe to others what you’ve been witnessing and the work that you’ve done.

Select Start to continue.

_items.body: You may feel that you don’t belong or that ‘home’ has become foreign to you.

It’s normal to feel exhausted and wound up at the same time. When you work in high stress environments, you become used to a high-activity level. Coming down from that takes time and it’s important to rest.
You can be overwhelmed by the pace at home regardless of the humanitarian environment you were working in.
It might seem that no one at home understands your experience and that everything people talk about seems trivial in comparison.

_graphic.alt: A humanitarian worker sting on some steps, outside a building, holding his head in his hands.

title: How to Manage Stress
body:
When returning home, allow for a period of adjustment and be prepared that it may be difficult.

These coping techniques, that you will have developed, will help you manage the stress of re-entering your home-life after being away.
instruction: Select each of the titles to find out more.

_graphic.alt: A group of happy friends meeting at a café and watching a tablet screen.

_items.title: Social Support
_items.body:
• Use the opportunity to re-connect with family and friends, but try not to have high expectations of them. Remember the time you were away may have changed you, but it’s likely that your family and friends will be the same.
  • Catch up on the things you missed while you were away. Engage in those activities that help you reconnect with what you enjoy about your culture.

_items.title: Health and Wellbeing
_items.body:
• Catch up on your sleep and spend a few days without any plans or commitments.
  • Try to engage in some physical activity. Go for a run or a long walk, for example.
  • It might actually be therapeutic to do your reports, giving you the opportunity to reflect on your experience.

_items.title: Personal Management
_items.body:
• Preparedness: Make sure that you take your full breaks and take advantage of any support offered by your organisation.
  • Meaning and Motivation: Talk about your time away and the things you experienced with a trusted friend or family member who is willing to give you time and help you to deepen your reflections.
  • It may also be helpful to talk to someone who can empathise with your views. Try to connect with others who have worked or volunteered internationally or far away from home.
  • Adaptability and Resourcefulness: If you don’t feel better after 3 months, and you’re still struggling to adapt to home-life make sure to seek additional support.

title: Introduction
body:
As we’ve discovered, it’s necessary and important to embed a wellness and resilience culture within humanitarian organisations.

As a manager, you, along with your organisation, are responsible for promoting the wellness and resilience of the workforce by putting policies and practices in place to support this.
instruction: Select each of the headings to find out more.

_graphic.alt: A group of Humanitarian workers attending classroom training.

_items.title: Duty of Care
_items.body: Providing wellbeing support for staff is now seen as an essential element of a Duty of Care Framework. You must demonstrate concern for your workers in terms of their physical and mental health. This shouldn't just be seen as a legal and moral duty - there's a clear business case, too.

_items.title: Benefits
_items.body: Frontline workers who are not supported can’t work productively, which in turn has a cost impact on the organisation. A wellness and resilience policy can help you identify affected individuals in your organisation.

_items.title: Embedding wellness and resilience
_items.body: As a manager, you can provide support by committing to create a work environment that systematically cares for the physical, mental, and psychological welfare of your workers.

title: The Cost of not Caring
body:
Understanding the support that your humanitarian workers need will benefit both the individual and your organisation.

Read the account from a humanitarian worker to see what happens when a wellness and resilience culture is absent from an organisation.
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: Saime, a humanitarian worker, had been deployed on surge to Iraq from her regular headquarters, and worked in Erbil for three months without a break.

_graphic.alt: Humanitarian worker, Saime looking out of a window with a cup of coffee in her hands.

_items.body: She was unable to take a break, as she did not qualify for the UN Rest and Recuperation entitlement, because she had only deployed for 12 weeks, not 13. Before she left Erbil, she asked her manager in headquarters if she could take a break before returning to work. However, due to pressing work commitments, she was asked to return to work immediately upon her return.

_graphic.alt: Saime looking tired, as she rests on her hands whist working on her laptop.

_items.body: She flew out of Erbil on a Friday. On the following Monday, she returned to her regular job working on humanitarian policy. Upon walking into her office that day, she was greeted, perhaps partially in jest, with, “Welcome back from your holiday in Iraq, now it’s time to do some real work.”

_graphic.alt: Saime with her colleagues in a meeting room.

_items.body: In the months that followed she was unable to take leave. Her manager displayed no interest in what she had experienced, and on the wellness front, she was neither offered nor informed of any support available should she need it.

_graphic.alt: Saime is close to tears in a quiet area of the office.

_items.body: She had a constant feeling of fatigue and was totally disengaged at work. She was turning up to work and just going through the motions; in other words, just doing enough to ‘stay out of trouble.’ This was the same person who had worked incredibly hard in Iraq and had a great reputation in the Erbil community. Now she was a different person; tired and disengaged, and no one appeared to care.

_graphic.alt: Saime holds her head in her hands as she’s sat at the computer.

_items.body:
There’s a cost of such indifference to the wellness of aid workers and their organisations. Although Saime was physically at work, her mind was absent. This is known as presenteeism; being on the job, but because of illness, stress, burnout or other medical conditions, not fully functioning. According to one study, presenteeism can cut individual productivity by one-third or more.

Content adapted from 7Piliers.com, credit: Brendan McDonald

_graphic.alt: Saime sitting with her head on the desk

title: A Caring Culture
body:
Humanitarian workers reported that a lack of managerial and organisational support is their biggest stressor.

If you’re actively involved in monitoring and maintaining high levels of wellbeing at work, you can help your workers to minimise stress and, in turn, have a positive impact on employee engagement and happiness.

Look at the case study to see how the programme has begun to change the culture at Save the Children International.
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: Save the Children International commissioned an important new programme in South Sudan to develop a comprehensive wellbeing, resilience and peer support system within their offices.

_graphic.alt: A group of affected people at the Save the Children camp in South Sudan.

_items.body:
South Sudan is the one of the most difficult contexts for aid workers and staff often report high levels of cumulative and traumatic stress and vicarious traumatisation.

This is due to a combination of a complex political environment, difficult working conditions, and isolation in remote field locations.

_graphic.alt: A line of affected people waiting at the Save the Children camp in South Sudan.

_items.body: Save the Children International trained two members of staff from each field location for a total of 21 focal points. The goal of the programme was for the focal points to provide regular information to staff on stress and resilience, as well as Psychological First Aid in the event of a critical incident.

_graphic.alt: A humanitarian worker speaking at a meeting.

_items.body: Save the Children International also conducted a staff-wide wellbeing survey so they could understand their sources of stress and wellbeing needs.

_graphic.alt: A humanitarian worker wearing the Save the Children overcoat.

_items.body: The survey showed that staff suffered from long working hours, they felt overwhelmed by the needs of those they were helping and many had signs of burnout and potential traumatic stress. The survey also showed that the staff found an incredible amount of support in each other and took great meaning from their work.

_graphic.alt: Humanitarian workers distributing supplies in affected areas.

_items.body: The programme was a useful intervention at the time and began to plant the seeds of a growing awareness of the importance of understanding stress and building resilience in challenging environments.

_graphic.alt: A happy toddler sitting in the middle of a heap of articles.

_items.title: Review your Policies
_items.body:
Review all of your policies to make sure that they are providing the right programmes and support to reduce stress for workers.

Even with the right policies in place to support wellness and resilience, it’s important to also review polices in order to ensure they support, not hinder, wellness and resilience.

_graphic.alt: A pile of papers on a desk.

_items.title: Anti-Discrimination Policies
_items.body: Make sure you have anti-discrimination policies in place to protect workers against gender, race, nationality or sexual orientation discrimination. Your policies should also prohibit bullying or sexual, racial and emotional harassment of any group or individual.

_graphic.alt: A set of diverse fingers belonging to the same hand with happy faces painted on them.

_items.title: Reduce Stress
_items.body: Make sure your policies around working processes and procedures are designed to reduce sources of stress. These may include areas such as benefits, decision-making procedures, workload rules and other human resources related issues.

_graphic.alt: A person practicing yoga by the sea.

_items.title: Regular Meetings with Staff
_items.body: Both individual meetings with staff members and group staff meetings are a great way to discuss any concerns and ensure that staff know they have a space where they can raise any concerns.  Staff meetings are also a good place to highlight successes and positive achievements the individual and team are making.

_graphic.alt: A group of people in discussion in an office.

_items.title: Evaluate Capabilities
_items.body: Carry out an assessment with your teams to assess their current capabilities and make sure that managers and team leaders have the right skills and behaviours to lead teams.

_items.title: Arrange Training
_items.body: If you identify gaps when carrying out the assessment, it’s important to arrange training for managers and team leaders, as poor management can be a major source of stress for workers.

_items.body: Anticipated Stresses: Give as much detail about the anticipated stresses of humanitarian work and highlight the risks faced by particular groups of workers.

Signs of Stress: Raise awareness about the mechanisms of stress response and how to recognise signs of stress, burnout, critical incident stress and vicarious traumatisation in individuals and colleagues.

Stress Management Techniques: Encourage practising specific stress management techniques and coping skills, such as relaxation techniques, anger management techniques, self-care and emphasise the value of sharing experiences with colleagues.
Team Work: Enable development of skills needed for working with a team that may include people of varying nationalities and both men and women.
Avoiding Bad Habits: Educate about the risks of common behaviours that are ineffective in coping with stress, such as heavy drinking, and smoking, isolating oneself or high-risk behaviours.

title: Monitoring
body:
Although the purpose of monitoring is to create a caring and enabling environment for the team, some people may see it as intrusive or controlling.

Therefore, it’s important to get the balance right. You can achieve this by helping your organisation to design policies and procedures that protect team members from misuse of the process and by encouraging team participation and cooperation. As a manager, it’s your responsibility to make sure that any concerns relating to the wellness of a team member are reported to you. This is necessary for taking appropriate measures. The team needs to be aware of who to report to and how reporting is captured. They need to know who should be approached if they want to share any concern or report an issue related to the wellness of colleague.

Let’s go through a case study to understand this further.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 1
_items.body: The manager of a large humanitarian team in Bangladesh began to notice that one staff member was working longer hours than his colleagues. He was very social when he first arrived, but has been withdrawing himself more and more from the team. The team has reported they have seen him working in the hospital until late at night and have heard him crying when talking to his family in the evenings. The manager has asked how he is doing and if the workload and the suffering he is witnessing is causing distress.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 2
_items.body: They went through social support, health and wellbeing, and personal management, which are the three points of resilience that had been presented at a team meeting and talked about what the worker could do. They also went through the signs of stress. The worker decided that he would work on his resilience action plan and then come back to the manager in a week’s time. If he still wasn’t feeling well, he could be sign-posted to specialised services.

title: Ongoing Support
body:
Ongoing support is important to bring a change in the culture around the importance of wellbeing. With effective management, you can create a culture of open communication and a strong support system to bring a positive change in the workplace.

In the previous topic, you read about Save the Children International and how its initiative to bring a cultural change in the organisation helped in developing a caring culture. The regular stress and resilience sessions conducted by the organisation and the peer support system helped in shaping up an ongoing support network in the organisation. This is a perfect example that shows how effective management can bring a cultural change in the way we work.

Oxfam also took a similar initiative to improve the wellbeing of its teams.
instruction: Select the arrow to find out more.

_items.body: As a part of Oxfam International, Oxfam GB also shares the same purpose and rights-based approach. Its aim is to address requirements of the people living in poverty and support them in their own attempts to bring about positive change and realise their rights.

_graphic.alt: A group of people near a water tap.

_items.body: Oxfam used both quantitative and qualitative data to identify an increase in organisational stress-related absence. This included individual risk assessments, the number of Staff Health interventions, outputs from team surveys on work-life balance and active monitoring of anxiety or stress-related absence statistics.

_graphic.alt: Two humanitarian workers having a discussion.

_items.body: As part of the annual Health & Safety Action Plan, the Office’s Health & Safety Committee found mechanisms to raise staff awareness of stress-related issues, and finding practical ways to support improvements in their wellbeing.

_graphic.alt: A hand holding the green ribbon symbol for Mental Health Awareness.

_items.body: Given the nature of their work, and the variety of workers and skill-sets involved, Oxfam developed a six-month campaign-based programme of events to raise awareness of the issues around the wellbeing of workers. The programme focused on five strands of wellbeing: mental, emotional, physical, social and environmental.

_graphic.alt: A group of humanitarian workers discussing the topic of wellbeing.

_items.body: Oxfam managed to initiate a change with its ongoing support to care for the wellbeing of its workers. The programme had a positive impact upon stress-related absence and helped in bringing a change in the culture of team and personal reflection on stress awareness.

title: Support Mechanisms
body:
As a manager, and a role model to your team, it’s important for you to demonstrate good practice behaviours.

In Topic 4 ‘Tackling Stress and Building Resilience’, you explored coping techniques around ‘social support’, ‘health and wellbeing’ and ‘personal management’ from a personal viewpoint. Now, think about ways you can support your workers in each of these areas.

Consider demonstrating resilience strategies in these three areas to bring about change in your organisation.

_graphic.alt: A group of people near a water tap.

title: Support Mechanisms
instruction: Select each of the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Social Support
_items.body: Take breaks and make time to connect with colleagues.

_items.title: Health and Wellbeing
_items.body:
• Take regular breaks and holidays, encourage stress-reducing activities in the office, eat well and talk about the importance of rest and exercise.
  • Organise lunch time recreational activities that promote health.
  • Work reasonable hours and encourage your team to do the same.

_items.title: Personal Management
_items.body:
Personal management has three subcategories:

  • Preparedness: Engage in personal development and encourage all team members to do the same.
  • Meaning and Motivation: Encourage regular meetings to talk about the meaning of the work your team is doing, what motivates them personally and how they’re feeling.
  • Adaptability and Resourcefulness: Communicate with team members and consult on problems and challenges in the workplace and seek creative solutions.

title: Crisis Support and Management
body:
Critical incidents or traumatic events are those events that are extremely threatening to the life or physical wellbeing of those involved. They’re accompanied by feelings of powerlessness, horror or terror.

Sometimes the term ‘critical incident’ is used broadly to describe a severely stressful event that has an unusually great impact on the individual and the team.

_graphic.alt: A destroyed building with surrounding debris.

title: Critical Incidents and Traumatic Events
body: After a traumatic event, it’s normal and healthy to react. People’s reactions will depend on the event, their exposure to it and their personal history.
instruction: Select the images to find out more.

_graphic.alt: alt text

_items.title: What are the first steps in the event of a critical incident?
_items.body:
Take the following steps in the first few hours to support your team members in the event of a critical incident:

  • Make sure they’re safe. Advise them to go to a place where they feel safe.
  • Advise them to connect with family and friends. Being with people whom they trust and rely on helps.
  • Advise them to follow only the reliable sources, be alert to social media sites to stay informed and be explicit about what they know and what they don’t know.

_graphic.alt: Sunrays beaming down from the top of a staircase.

_items.title: What support do they need in the first hours, days?
_items.body:
You can offer your support in the following ways:

  • Make sure that the person is in a safe place and provide all basic necessities such as time off, food, shelter and clothing if needed.
  • Help people in resuming their normal routine.
  • Normalise what the person is experiencing. Provide information on common reactions.
  • Use psychological first aid to help the person feel stable and to make an initial risk assessment.
  • Provide information about available support services and / or referral options for confidential reviews.

_graphic.alt: Hands of people reaching out to each other.

_items.title: When to sign-post for other services?
_items.body:
Consider sign-posting team members to additional services in the following situations:

  • They have no one to share their feelings with.
  • They feel overwhelmed by sadness, anxiety or nervousness.
  • They feel that they’re not returning to normal after six weeks.
  • Their nightmares are preventing them from getting sleep.
  • They’re struggling to get on with those close to them.
  • They want to withdraw from other people more and more.
  • They feel numb and notice that they increasingly don’t care.
  • Their work is deteriorating and it’s difficult to concentrate.
  • Those around them suggest they seek help.
  • They only feel alive in high risk or very stressful situations.
  • They’re drinking or smoking too much, or using drugs or other high-risk strategies to cope with their feelings.
  • They bury themselves in work in order to avoid their feelings.
  • Even in a safe relationship, they’re not able to talk about the traumatic event.
  • They feel they’re the only ones suffering like this.

_graphic.alt: Speech bubbles with the message ‘We Can Help’.

title: Case Study
body: Now, let’s go through a case study to understand the relevance of responding to critical incidents in order to support wellness and resilience.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 1
_items.body: You’re the Area Manager for your organisation, based in Jordan. It was an ordinary day at the office when you got a call from HR. A team that included the Head of Office were visiting the Yemen office and they were also planning an observation visit to a hospital.

_graphic.alt: A male Area Manager speaking on the phone.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 2
_items.body: During the visit, there was an air strike on the hospital and Taghreed, the Jordanian Head of Office sustained some injuries. They’re relatively minor (cuts and bruises), but she’s very shaken up. You have been asked to support Taghreed.

_graphic.alt: A medical practitioner looking at Taghreed’s injuries.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 3
_items.body: Taghreed is 32 years old and has been working in the post as a Head of Office for seven months. She’s from Jordan and lives with her family (husband and two children) in Amman. She’s new to the organisation and was previously working for an NGO in one of the Syrian refugee camps in Jordan.  While working in the camps, she experienced a difficult incident where she was held at gunpoint for several hours by a man with mental health issues. The incident was resolved, but she has told you in confidence that she still has nightmares about it.

_graphic.alt: Taghreed with her husband and children.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 4
_items.body:
It’s the evening of the event and you’re at the hospital waiting for Taghreed. She feels most guilty about the fact that it was her idea to visit the hospital and feels it’s her fault they were there. When the air strike hit, she thought that she was going to die. She keeps remembering that she froze when the incident started, unable to move or figure out what to do. As she talks to you, you notice that she begins to freeze up, going quite blank and quiet.

What are your first steps?

      1. Ask what would help her to feel safe?
      2. Acknowledge what has happened without going into great detail.

Talk to her about what’s going to happen next. You will help her to reach her family and the organisation will support her.

To learn more about supporting adults: http://www.who.int/mental_health/publications/guide_field_workers/en/

To learn more about supporting children: https://kayaconnect.org/course/view.php?id=781

_graphic.alt: Taghreed holding the Area Manager’s hand.

_items.title: Case Study: Part 5
_items.body:
A month later, you discover that Taghreed has been calling in sick regularly and her direct manager has mentioned that she seems to be having a hard time concentrating. When you see her in the office, she looks distracted, she hasn’t been looking after her personal appearance and she appears very tired.

What should you do next?

  • Sign-post for additional services

title: More about Wellbeing
body: Credit: Video created by Save the Children for the FIELD programme.
instruction: Select the Play button to start the video.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
What is wellbeing?

Well, the World Health Organisation defines it as a state in which every individual realizes his or her own potential, can cope with the normal stresses of life and is able to make a contribution to her or his community.

How would others describe it? Some see it as a state of fulfilment, feeling whole…. Others describe it as their body, mind and spirit being at ease….

It might be described as having a good balance between personal and professional life… Or being able to manage the ups and downs of life. Wellbeing is not just about how to recover from stress or burnt out, it’s also about building resilience to the challenges we might face. It isn’t something we either have or don’t have – Resilience can be developed.

If we can build the resilience of our teams then we reduce stress and burnout. Staff turnover goes down, and our ability to help the communities we are working with increases.

Not everyone sees the importance of wellbeing: Some might say ‘This is an emergency, we don’t have time for this kind of stuff’ or ‘If you are not tough enough, perhaps you shouldn’t be working in emergency response’. Another reaction might be ‘It’s not my job as a field manager to look after my team. I am there to get the job done.

Perhaps you have had these doubts? But think about it:

The situations we are working in are outside of most people’s day to day experiences. As managers, we have a duty of care to our staff and ourselves. We can’t meet the needs of those affected by the emergency if we are, ourselves, stressed or burnt out.

You might ask…‘But how can I make a difference?’ Firstly, Recognise the different health and wellbeing challenges that staff face. Then create a healthy working environment that nurtures resilience. Identify techniques that help build resilience and adopt them within your team…and recognise and monitor signs of stress in yourself and the people you manage.

Remember, stress can be influenced by many factors including culture, length of assignment and gender expectations – don’t treat all situations the same. By looking after the wellbeing of yourself and your team, you make a real impact on the communities you are there to support. Everyone benefits.

title: Moving On
body:
When one of your workers finishes an assignment, it’s not the end of the story.

It’s important to put in place procedures for supporting them at the end and beyond the end of their assignment. You can achieve this by:

  • Creating clear processes.
  • Sign-posting.
  • Conducting thorough debrief and assessment.
  • Providing any necessary support and guidance.
instruction: Select the icons to find out more.

_graphic.title: A young humanitarian worker in discussion with the manager, Hands of an elderly person.

_items.body: Operational Debriefing: Find out what the individuals observed, experienced and learned during their contract, and look at the ways in which your organisation could benefit from this experience. You can also talk about any significant stress they faced and how they managed it. Discuss if they would like additional support and then sign-post them to the relevant services if available.

_graphic.alt: A young humanitarian worker in discussion with the manager.

_items.body:
Unplanned Endings: Unplanned endings are when the length of a role a humanitarian worker is engaged for is cut short. This can be because of several reasons such as evacuation, an unanticipated termination of a programme, or a team member’s personal needs.

In the event of unplanned endings, make sure you also consider the needs of all staff, as they often have strong, emotional and personal bonds with colleagues. After an unplanned ending, provide support as needed to team members and remind them of their individual resilience plans.

title: Course Outcomes and Next Steps
body:
Thanks for taking the time to complete the wellness and resilience course for Managers.

You should now have an understanding of various wellness and resilience techniques to apply during stressful situations. You will also have learned about the changes you can make within your organisation by embedding a wellness and resilience culture. You should now be able to exemplify the strategies and techniques you’ve explored in this e-learning course to set an example to your teams of humanitarian workers and colleagues.

You will now be able to:

  • Identify the nature of stress.
  • Describe the importance of staying well and resilient.
  • Identify signs of stress.
  • Develop strategies to effectively manage and reduce stress.
  • Develop and strengthen personal resilience and wellbeing.
  • Put in place practices and organisational structures that foster wellness and resilience.

We encourage you to share this course with your humanitarian workers and colleagues. We also recommend you include this course when on-boarding new humanitarian workers.

Humanitarian workers taking this course will also be a step closer to achieving CHCF Competencies and Core Behaviours of ‘maintaining professionalism’ and ‘adapting and coping’.

Please go to the Resources section where you will find helpful information and sign-posting to further your understanding of Wellness and Resilience.
